did.unittitle: Educational Technology Services Records
did.abstract: This collection contains the records of Educational Technology Services.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in one series: Great Courses.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Tufts Educational Technology Services (ETS) is a department within Tufts Technology Services. Members of ETS are trained to help Tufts faculty and staff of courses to incorporate technology into their academic programs. ETS also leads workshops throughout the school-year for faculty to learn new technologies. As of 2017, the department is led by Paul Bergen, Director of Educational Technology and Learning Spaces. Starting in 2010 and in following years, the group quickly gained importance across all four Tufts campus', as integrating technology into the classroom became vital for engaging and connecting with students. Projects undertaken have included supporting instructors with "Instructional Continuity" when a class is cancelled, as well as helping faculty adjust to changes in university-wide learning management systems. ETS has also helped instructors to make course resources accessible to students, aiding with the publishing of lecture videos and notes through different platforms.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Educational Technology Services Records, 2014. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing of Great Courses material completed by Margaret Peachy and Leah Edelman in 2017. Materials were imported into the DL and digital objects created in ArchivesSpace. Received order was maintained. An item-level inventory and series-level description were created and the finding aid was updated at the time of processing.Â

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Blackboard Course Management System, 2000-2011. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: University Information Technology Records, 1988-2012. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains material relating to Great Courses at Tufts, including PDF files of assignments, bibliographies, focus questions, notes, slides, and the syllabus for Philosophy 167, as well as video files of the class lectures.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Copyright to all materials created by Tufts University employees in the course of their work is held by the Trustees of Tufts University.

did.unittitle: Great Courses

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Slides are available to Tufts Community users only. Non-Tufts users may request access using 'add to list.'

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Educational Technology Services, 2017, accession UA-2018-021.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in received order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains PDF files of assignments, bibliographies, focus questions, notes, slides, and the syllabus for Philosophy 167, as well as video files of the class lectures. It also contains a webcrawl of the website conducted in 2017 that can be made available to members of the Tufts community in the DCA reading room.

did.unittitle: Assignment 1 for Philosophy 167.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Prepare a "legal brief" (5 to 7 pages long) for someone charged with judging Galileo.

did.unittitle: Assignment 2 for Philosophy 167.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Write a 5 to 7 page paper comparing the evidence available as of 1651 for the law of free fall, the law of parabolic trajectory, and the law of inertia, respectively.

did.unittitle: Assignment 3 for Philosophy 167.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In a brief paper (5-7 pages) explain what difference Halley would have said the purely mathematical discoveries presented in the De Motu made to the evidential status first of Kepler's "laws" and second of the "laws" of free-fall, projectile motion, and what we now call inertia.

did.unittitle: Initial Paper Assignment for Philosophy 167.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Initial assignment for a short (2-3) page paper. Think of this exercise as an initial attempt to state the evidence problem posed by the three "chief world systems" as understood in 1600.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 1 - Introduction: The Discovery of High-Quality Evidence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video sets the expectations of the course, reviews the syllabus, and briefly discusses history and philosophy of science. Opening line: "This is a course totally focused on answering the question: How did we first come to have high quality evidence in any of the sciences?" Duration: 16:50 minutes. Section: Class 1, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 2 - Basic Astronomy: The Celestial Sphere.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video provides a brief introduction to astronomy. Opening line: "So let's start looking at this. How did we first come to have high quality evidence in any of the sciences? Interestingly enough, it comes almost entirely from the evidence in question, comes almost entirely from the skies." Duration: 8:50 minutes. Section: Class 1, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 3 - Inequalities: The Sun and the Moon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video reviews the concept of inequality, the Sidereal day, the line of nodes and First Inequality of the Planets. Opening line: "All right. Now, we start getting the complications. The technical term is inequality. What inequality means is non-uniformity in motion." Duration: 6:51 minutes. Section: Class 1, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 4 - Inequalities: The Planets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video introduces the concept of Retrograde Motion. Opening line: "But now on top on that, the planets do something that the sun and moon do not do at all." Duration: 6:39 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 5 - Accounts of the Planetary Inequalities: the Babylonians, and Eudoxus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video introduces the concept of tropical period and synoptic period. Opening line: "The first sensible set of predictions on this is by the Babylonians. They discovered that if you looked for a long enough period you would see the patterns I just showed you start repeating." Duration: 8:48 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 6 - Accounts of the Planetary Inequalities: Aristotle's Principles of Celestial Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video reviews Aristotle's concept of the celestial run and introduces us to Ptolemy and Apollonius and other important thinkers. Opening line: "Aristotle has a separate work called On the Heavens, De Caelo, in which he doesn't so much talk about Eudoxus' model as he backs off and spends some time doing essentially philosophic reasoning about what has to be true of the celestial run." Duration: 10:39 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 7 - Evidence Problems: Real vs. Apparent Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video reviews Apollonius' Theorem. Opening line: "I'm only gonna go about five more minutes before I take a break, but I wanna look briefly at Apollonius' Theorem." Duration: 10:55 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 8 - The Almagest: a Summary of Books I-XIII.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video introduces Ptolemy. Opening segment: "Has everybody who wants to be on trunk given me their information? All right, it'll be up here after class. Please do so, cuz I can put you on, but I can't do it if I don't know your email. All right, Ptolemy." Duration: 12:59 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 9 - The Ptolemaic Model: the Solar, Planetary, and Lunar Theories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video continues the discusion about Ptolemy and introduces the bisection of eccentricity. Opening line: "Now the overall system, this is a schematic, totally non to scale 100% not to scale. To begin with other than the moon Ptolemy had no idea how far any object was away." Duration: 13:16 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 10 - Ptolemy's Great Contribution: the Bisection of the Eccentricity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video continues the discusion about Ptolemy and reviews further the bisection of eccentricity, concluding that Ptolemy is twice violating Aristotle; the earth is not in the center and the motions are not uniform. Opening line: "All right let me go back now to Ptolemy and the bisection of the eccentricity." Duration: 7:38 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 11 - Reproducing the Retrograde Loops: Evidence for the Ptolemaic Model.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video reviews Jim Evan's approach to the Hipparchian model and retrograde loops. Opening line: "Okay that's the background. I'm now gonna present Evans' approach to this." Duration: 7:47 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 12 - Calculating the Loops: Using Observations to Get the Orbital Elements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video discusses Noel Swerdlow's paper. Opening line: "Swerdlow, in an attempt to explain that, and it's in this paper, gives you a way as he says at the bottom here where I marked it out. Gives you a way of having the radius ratio." Duration: 5:48 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 13 - The Goals of Ptolemaic Astronomy: Qualitative, not Quantitative, Accuracy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video reviews Ptolemaic Astronomy. Opening line: "At any rate, though, it's very good science." Duration: 7:05 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 1 - Part 14 - The Implications of Ptolemaic Astronomy: Successes, Shortcomings, and the Essence of Good Science.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This video reviews concludes the first lecture, with an assessment of Ptolemaic Astronomy. Opening line: "So what's the achievement of Ptolemaic astronomy and what are the shortcomings? Let's start with the achievement." Duration: 8:55 minutes. Segment: Class 1, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 1 - Turning Data into Evidence: Evidence and Hypotheses in Ptolemaic Astronomy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Provides a definition of the term 'working hypothesis'; stresses that evidence is a relation between data and claims that reach beyond them; reviews three working hypothesis of celestial mechanics. Opening line: "All right, so let me start. I use the term working hypothesis very differently from its standard use." Duration: 16:02 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 2 - Islamic Astronomy: The Standard Story.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Places the publication of Copernicus' De Revolutionibus in light of the printing press; stresses that the printing press transformed higher learning; reviews how ancient learning came into western Europe via Islam; discusses the rise of the universities, textbooks, and a translation of the Almagest. Opening line: "All right. Now, I'm not going to put up a slide immediately because I don't have an appropriate slide to discuss with this right away." Duration: 7:01 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 3 - Islamic Astronomy: Ibn al-Shatir, and Innovative Astronomical Research in the Islamic World.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Tells how Edward S. Kennedy acquired a manuscript that turns out to be a comprehensive alternative to Ptolemaic astronomy by Ibn al-Shatir; emphasizes that Copernicus was indebted to Islamic science. Opening line: "In 1957, Edward S Kennedy, a professor at the American university in Beirut, Lebanon." Duration: 12:45 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 4 - Regiomontanus: Some Key Pre-Copernicus Publications in Astronomy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Introduces Georg von Peuerbach and Regiomontanus (Johannes Mller von Knigsberg); discusses the project to print in the original Greek the whole of the Almagest, Euclid, Apollonius, and Archimedes. Opening line: "All right, so now I'm back to what happened in Europe after 1450." Duration: 7:22 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 5 - Copernicus: a Brief Biography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A brief biography of Copernicus. Opening line: "So let me tell you a little about Copernicus now, 1473 to 1543, that means he lived 70 years." Duration: 6:39 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 6 - Copernicus' System: The Postulates, and Some Solutions to Classic Problems in Ptolemaic Astronomy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A brief review of Copernicus' System. Opening line: "All right, with that as background, let's look at the commentary, all it's very clean." Duration: 11:24 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 7 - Heliocentrism: Copernicus' Mathematical Transform (of Ibn al-Shatir's Mathematical Transform) of Ptolemy's epicyclic system.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews the process by which Copernicus arrived at Heliocentrism. Opening line: "How did he get to heliocentricity? Well here's a passage from Almagest." Duration: 8:38 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 8 - Copernicus' Place in the History of Astronomy: In What Senses Did Copernicus Inaugurate a Revolution?.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews the challenge Copernicus posed to religious authority, and the dominant worldview. Opening line: "There were Copernican revolutions. The one revolution is a challenge to authority." Duration: 5:51 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 9 - The Structure of De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium: a Summary of What Copernicus Did.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: An Overview of the De Revolutionibus. Opening line: "All right, so the next slide is from Tom Coon of course." Duration: 9:41 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 10 - Eliminating the Equant: the Method of Triangulations, and the Presupposition of Ptolemaic Theory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Detailed explanation with an example on removing the equant. Opening line: "All right. How to get rid of the equant. I'm gonna be quick on this." Duration: 9:55 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 11 - A Possible Reason Why Copernicanism Was Accepted: Inference to the Best Explanation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Although there is no empirical grounds whatsoever for preferring Copernican Astronomy to Ptolemaic Astronomy, Copernicanism was accepted. This video begins to propose an answer as to why. Opening line: "All right let me ask a question, and and I'm almost done with Copernicus but I want to pause for a moment and ask why should anybody at the time prefer Copernican astronomy to Ptolemaic astronomy." Duration: 8:21 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 12 - An Alternative Reason Why Copernicus's Theory Should Have Been Preferred to Ptolemy's: Bringing Empirical Evidence to Bear on Scientific Questions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Although there is no empirical grounds whatsoever for preferring Copernican Astronomy to Ptolemaic Astronomy, Copernicanism was accepted. This video concludes with an answer as to why. Specifically, the system was seen as beautiful. Opening line: "I'm gonna give you a different reason for preferring Copernican astronomy, though." Duration: 5:16 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 13 - Tycho at Hven: the Collection of a Preciseand UniformBody of Observations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A brief biography of Tycho Brahe at Hven; his removal from his post; transition to modern astronomy. Opening line: "All right, Tycho Brahe. This is a quote from the best biography we have of him." Duration: 11:13 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 14 - Theory, Empirically Driven: Tycho's Account of Solar Motion, His Attempts to Correct Observational Error, and His Search for Stellar Parallax.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A continued examination of Tycho Brahe at Hven and his data collection techniques; reviews the issues of parallax correction and atmospheric refraction correction. Opening line: "From 1578 to 1597, he did observations of the sun crossing the meridian altitudes." Duration: 10:01 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 2 - Part 15 - A Crisis in Mathematical Astronomy: the Calculational Equivalency of Three Different Systems, and the Attraction of Pyrrhonism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Synopsis: Points out that there is no way to choose between the 3 systems if the only form of empirical data we have are observed longitudes and latitudes; places astronomy in the historical context of the mid-16th century and reviews the rise of Pyrrhonism. Opening line: "At any rate, what I want to lead up to now, and I've got four minutes, I'll do my best with this. What we've got here in the 1590s is three systems." Duration: 7:01 minutes. Segment: Class 2, Part 15.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 1 - Astronomical Data in 1600: the Evidential Challenges in Empirical Astronomy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews the state of mathematical astronomy in 1600. Describes how Kepler gained access to Tycho Brahe's observations. Opening line: "A couple of remarks from last week. First Melissa, I think it was Melissa, that's I spoke to you as you walked in who made the remark about Tycho having a gold nose." Duration: 13:17 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 2 - Kepler: a Brief Biography, and the Appreciation of Physical Theory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Gives a brief biography of Johannes Kepler. Provides the background in which Kepler did his work. Opening line: "So a little about Kepler. Kepler was born in 1571, he died in 1630, so he didn't quite make 60 years old." Duration: 13:48 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 3 - Towards Disentangling the Various Observed Motions: Astronomia Nova, Real Planetary Movement, and the First and Second Inequalities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Introduces Kepler's arguments on how to analyze the motions of the planets. Gives some history on his book came to be published. Describes details about retrograde motion and the implications for describing orbits. Opening line: "In the introduction you'll be reading next week, this is Astronomia Nova." Duration: 6:29 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 4 - The Problems Kepler Faced: Imprecision in Observation, Interpolation, and the Observational Data Themselves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Kepler's analysis of the sources of error in astronomical observations and predictions. Includes observational error, parallax, refraction, and optics. Discusses implications of errors in identifying discrepancies between theory and observation. Opening line: "The approach Kepler takes in Astronomia Nova is to start with various approaches, all three." Duration: 6:40 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 5 - Astronomia Nova: the Overall Structure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Outlines the book Astronomia Nova. Describes the organization of the book as a flowchart of reasoning. Opening line: "At any rate, let's turn to the book itself. This is the title page in English, as translated by Bill Donahue." Duration: 7:32 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 6 - Astronomia Nova, Part 1: the Actual Sun, an Experimentum Crucis, and the Problem of Latitudes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes Kepler's argument for basing orbital predictions on the actual position of the Sun instead of the hypothetical mean position. Opening line: "All right, let's go back to part one. I said what point in part one is to establish that we should be referring all motions to the actual Sun, not to the mean Sun." Duration: 9:22 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 7 - Astronomia Nova, Part 2: the Vicarious Hypothesis, and Mars' Heliocentric Longitudes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Shows how Kepler analyzed the orbit of Mars. Follows Kepler's reasoning which removes the Ptolemaic concept of the equant. Opening line: "Part 2. He now decides to take a first shot at the Mars orbit." Duration: 10:52 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 8 - Astronomia Nova, Part 3: the Earth-Sun Orbitand Bisected Eccentricityin the Copernican/Tychonic Systems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Kepler's analysis of the Earth's orbit. Concludes that the Earth's orbit is eccentric. Opening line: "Which gets me to part three. And I stay with this for a moment." Duration: 8:45 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 9 - Astronomia Nova, Part 3: Transferring the Argument to the Ptolemaic System.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Shows how Kepler's eccentric orbits are transferred into the Ptolemaic system. Opening line: "That's great if Mars is going around the sun. What about Ptolemy?" Duration: 9:58 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 10 - Astronomia Nova, Part 4: the Area Rule, the Oval, and the Ellipse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes Kepler's new rule that the orbital velocity is inversely proportional to the distance from the Sun. Opening line: "Okay, here's where we've gotten to. We've gotten to where the Earth-Sun orbit has got bisected eccentricity, and therefore, Kepler can go ahead and say velocity in the Mars orbit is inversely proportional to the distance of Mars from the Sun." Duration: 8:40 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 11 - Astronomia Nova, Part 4: Using Triangulation to Show that Mars' Trajectory is An Oval.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Shows how Kepler proves the orbit of Mars is an oval. Opening line: "And then, he does now the typical Kepler thing to do. He starts looking at other ways of considering this whole manner." Duration: 6:22 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 12 - Astronomia Nova, Part 4: the Diametral Distance Rule, and Settling on the Ellipse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Shows how Kepler derived the elliptical shape of orbits. Opening line: "Okay, then he notices something that really strikes him and I'll just read it. The breadth of the lunule of Chapter 46 above." Duration: 11:49 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 13 - Physical Theorizing: a Magnetic Account of Planetary Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Kepler's magnetic theory of planetary orbits. Opening line: "He now asks what's the physics of this?" Duration: 7:10 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 3 - Part 14 - Accepting the Account: Evidential Arguments for Kepler's Innovations, and the Extent to Which Three Interrelated Principles Hold.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes Kepler's innovations and the evidence supporting them. Opening line: "So, look, there are questions of evidence here. There are really five principles, and in the notes I go through all five." Duration: 13:12 minutes. Segment: Class 3, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 1 - Working Hypotheses: Kepler, and the 1911 Solvay Conference.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews the issues facing Kepler; provides the parallel example of the 1911 Solvay Conference. Opening line: "So the question came, I'll reword it for him and make it more of an affront to me than he was prepared to do." Duration: 7:15 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 2 - Kepler's Achievement: Five Innovations, and the Large Jump in Calculational Accuracy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews the five innovations in planetary theory that got introduced in Astronomia Nova. Opening line: "I'm just going to work through the slides. This is not going to be so much a technical lecture as last week was." Duration: 6:35 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 3 - Review of Astronomonia Nova: the Method, and the Evidence for the Particular Reforms Employed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Further review of the Astronomonia Nova. Opening line: "Okay, I wanna do a little more review of Astronomia Nova trying to now drive home more of what was done and we'll come back and look at the problems." Duration: 14:17 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 4 - Felicitous Circumstances: Why Kepler Achieved What He Did.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Provides context for understanding Kepler's personality and his achievement. Opening line: "The question here that I posed, why Kepler?" Duration: 4:45 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 5 - Kepler's Biography: Comments on His Life and His Publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A brief biographical sketch of Kepler. Opening line: ""Okay, this is the rest of his life. He lived to be, it turns out, 58 years old." Duration: 12:49 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 6 - Celestial Harmonies: Nested Platonic Solids, Physical Theorizing, and the 3/2 Power Rule.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews Mysterium Cosmographicum and the Harmonices Mudni; discusses harmony and congruence in geometrical forms, physical phenomena and harmonies. Opening line: "This is the picture, I'll show you a more dramatic form, from Mysterium Cosmographicum." Duration: 7:14 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 7 - The Epitome of Copernican Astronomy: Structure of the Book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Overview of Epitome Astronomiae Copernicanae. Opening line: "All right, The Epitome's worth, I'm not gonna spend a lot of time on details, but I wanna move through the structure of the book because it's so striking." Duration: 10:53 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 8 - The Epitome of Copernican Astronomy: the Physics of Diametral Distance, Area Rule, and Ellipse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A more in-depth examination of Epitome Astronomiae Copernicanae, focusing on the physics of diametral distance, area rule, and ellipse. Opening line: "This is about the diameter of distance rule." Duration: 6:59 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 9 - Projectibility: Extending Kepler's Results to the Other Planets, and Indefinitely Throughout Time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Asks what grounds did Kepler have for projecting his result for Mars? Opening line: "I'm introducing a word here from Philosophy of Science, but it's not the word normally used." Duration: 7:06 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 10 - The Rudolphine Tables: Kepler's Autobiographic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: An overview of the title page of the Rudolphine Tables. Opening line: "All right this is the title page of the Rudolphine Tables. You'll notice so many features about Kepler here." Duration: 1:49 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 11 - Keplerian Orbital Theory: Defining the Keplerian Ellipse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews Kepler's orbital theory by way of the ellipse. Opening line: "So, how do you define a Keplerian ellipse? Well, his way of defining it is, the first thing you do is locate aphelion and. You do that by where it's fastest in the sky versus where it's slowest in the sky." Duration: 9:59 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 12 - Calculational Complications: Kepler's Equation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: An overview of Kepler's equation and why many resisted his area rule. Opening line: "This is Kepler's Problem, and this is what, one of the reasons offered for why people resisted the area rule." Duration: 4:45 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 13 - Galileo: the Assigned Reading, and the Significance of Sidereus Nuncius and Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Overview of the assigned readings. Opening line: "Second thing is the reading for next week. I've already told you, say some more about it, and there's a problem." Duration: 5:29 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 14 - The Nomological Nature of Generalization: Kepler's Five so-called "Laws", and the Issue of Projectability.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Introduces Kepler's laws. Opening line: "So we call them Kepler's laws, in particular the ellipse and the area rule." Duration: 10:29 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 15 - Varieties of Generalization: Exact, Essentially Exact, and Approximate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Asks whether the generalizations exact, essentially exact, merely approximate? Opening line: "This is a more subtle set of distinctions. I threw it out, the top one, last week. And I can reinforce it now. It's very, very much present in Kepler." Duration: 6:24 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 15.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 16 - Kepler's Three Arguments: From Observations and Reformations of Astronomical Procedures, in Astronomia Nova; From Physical Principles, in Epitome; Comparison Between Calculation and Observation, in Rudolphine Tables.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A review of Kepler's evidential reasoning. Opening line: "Kepler gives three types of evidential reasoning. I'm gonna let you read this on your own, you have it. But they're so different from one another, and it enormously complicates the question of why Kepler did not have more influence than he did." Duration: 5:36 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 16.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 4 - Part 17 - Evidence Problems: Those Fundamental to Orbital Astronomy, and Those Recognized by Kepler.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Review of the key points from the lecture. Opening line: "All right a couple of final slides, we're going to leave Kepler almost for good but I want to just, given what we've had from him, I just want to see we've learned." Duration: 9:34 minutes. Segment: Class 4, Part 17.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 1 - Individuals and Communities: Kepler, Galileo, Descartes, Huygens, Newton, and the Scientific Community as a Whole.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses the leading figures which are central to the course: Galileo, Descartes, Huygens, Newton, and Kepler. Opening line: "So look. Tonight, we're switching to the second of the five leading figures we're gonna study this semester, namely Galileo" Duration: 5:57 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 2 - Galileo Galilei: Publications and Polemics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Lists Galileo's three most important works, and discusses the role of polemics in science. Opening line: "Galileo's publications. Three of the books listed up here and by any imaginable standards monuments of Western Civilization." Duration: 9:39 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 3 - Galileo: Biography (1564-1616).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes the early part of Galileo's life, up until De revolutionibus is put on the index by the inquisition. Opening line: "This is his life up to a key event, March 3rd, 1616." Duration: 9:25 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 4 - Sidereus Nuncius: the Discovery of the Galilean Moons, and the Lunar Topography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Siderius Nuncius, in which Galileo published his discovery of the four largest moons of Jupiter and his telescopic survey of the surface of the moon. Opening line: "So that's the original title page of Sidereus Nuncius." Duration: 8:59 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 5 - Telescopes: Keplerian Telescopes, Galileo's Original Design, and Spherical and Chromatic Aberration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes early telescope design, limitations of optics, and the quality of Galileo's telescope. Opening line: "So the obvious question that people started asking. Remember, Aristotle said, save the phenomena. The phenomena are visible appearances. These aren't visible." Duration: 9:53 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 6 - Letters on Sunspots: the Phases of Venus, and the Demise of Ptolemaic Astronomy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Galileo's Letters on Sunspots, in which he publishes his observations of sunspots and the phases of Venus, implying that Venus orbits the Sun. Opening line: "In the letters on sunspots, there are various points I'll come back to the others." Duration: 12:34 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 7 - Galileo: Biography (1616-1642), and Some Details of the Trial.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes Galileo's life from 1616 until his death. Opening line: "So, this is the rest of his life. The decree of the Congregation of the Index prohibits Copernicus' De Revolutionibus until corrected and made more hypothetical." Duration: 9:39 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 8 - Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems: Aesthetic Arguments for Copernicanism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes the virulent debate between proponents of the Ptolemaic and Copernican systems. Opening line: "This is The Assayer. It's said to be a reply to Lothario Sarsi." Duration: 11:43 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 9 - Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems: Galileo's Theory of the Tides.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes Galileo's theory of tides and how it implies that the Earth rotates. Opening line: "Then we get to day four and this is again the summary of the argument." Duration: 9:14 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 10 - Galileo's Trial: The Sentencing, and Galileo's Abjuration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses the sentencing of Galileo for heresy, and his abjuration. Opening line: "At any rate, let's look at the trial for the moment." Duration: 7:24 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 11 - Astronomy After Galileo: Important Figures in the Field.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Lists some of the important people who followed in the steps of Kepler and Galileo over the next few decades. Opening line: "I've ended up with forty-five minutes instead of an hour to try to talk about what's technically the assimilation of the two revolutions." Duration: 5:11 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 12 - Pierre Gassendi and the Transit of Mercury: the Elliptical Orbits, the Sizes of the Planets, and their Heliocentric Distances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Follows the work of Pierre Gassendi, who observed the 1631 transit of Mercury across the Sun predicted by Kepler, and revised Mercury's orbit. Opening line: "All right, the important one here immediately is Gassendi." Duration: 9:27 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 13 - Jeremiah Horrocks: Finding the Mean Distance of Venus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes the work of Jeremiah Horrocks, who revised Kepler's Rudolphine Tables, particularly for the orbit of Venus. Opening line: "Now we get to Horrocks. We know remarkably little about Jeremiah Horrocks." Duration: 12:06 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 14 - Further Improvements in Empirical Astronomy: Horrocks' Theory of the Moon, and the Keplerian Telescope.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Focuses on the lunar orbit proposed by Horrocks, and on the growing use of Keplerian telescopes. Opening line: "The other thing he does is he doesn't like Kepler's theories of the moon because they violate the area rule." Duration: 6:56 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 5 - Part 15 - Open Questions in Astronomy: 1542 versus 1642.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes the dramatic change in the focus of astronomy over the century leading up to Galileo's death in 1642. Opening line: "As of 1542, that's the year before Copernicus published De Rev, there were two questions before on the forefront of astronomy." Duration: 4:03 minutes. Segment: Class 5, Part 15.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 1 - Introduction to Mechanics- Brief Review of Astronomical Questions, and the Major Figures in the Science of Machines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Introduces machines and the mechanics of motion along with the key figures in the science of machines. Opening line: "This is the last slide from last time. I'm not gonna go back over it. It's got these six questions, but we're shifting tonight away from Astronomy for five weeks." Duration: 7:41 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 2 - Archimedes- Galileo's Model, and the Principle of the Lever.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Brief introduction to Archimedes and his influence on Galileo; discusses the Principle of the Lever. Opening line: "What I do wanna do is spend a moment on Archimedes." Duration: 8:24 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 3 - 'Mechanics' and Astronomy- Comparing the Sciences of Celestial and Local Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Compares the science of Celestial and Local Motion. Opening line: "So 1638 is when two new sciences came out. And I want to compare and contrast, as of 1638 where things stood in celestial motion versus motion near the surface of the Earth." Duration: 8:59 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 4 - Two New Sciences- an Overview.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Overview of Galileo's Discourses and Mathematical Demonstrations Relating to Two New Sciences. Opening line: "That's the title page of the original, there are a lot of interesting things in it." Duration: 10:23 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 5 - The Art of Theory Construction- Apollonian Parameters of Orbital Theory, and Galileo's Science of Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews Apollonius of Perga's orbital theory, and Galileo's science of materials. Opening line: "Okay with that said, let's take the Apollonian parameters." Duration: 6:42 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 7 - Pendulums- Isochronism, and the Problem of Resistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Galileo's pendulem experiment. Opening line: "Now, on his claim about the pendulums. This is rather distressing, I'm just gonna read the whole passage out because it's so striking." Duration: 10:12 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 8 - Uniform Motion- the Exactness of Geometry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses uniform motion; Euclidean geometry and geometry. Opening line: "All right now we go to uniform motion and I get to start showing you the way he conceptualized things." Duration: 9:41 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 9 - A New Approach- Emphasizing Mathematical Tractability.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses the Archimedes sparrow; spirals; and mathematical tractability. Opening line: "I wanna start now with this very opening paragraph and a half on the section on naturally accelerated motion." Duration: 8:53 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 10 - Uniformly Accelerated Motion- the Primacy of Time, and the Mean Speed Theorem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews concepts of motion, distance and time; defines the mean speed theorem. Opening line: "Now he has a problem. Why equal increments of speed and equal time can equal times instead of equal increments of speed over equal increments of distance?" Duration: 10:45 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 11 - Empirical Approaches to Local Motion- Evidence Problems, and the Confirmation of Striking Predictions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews empirical approaches to local motion; Galileo's approach to developing evidence. Opening line: "We are ready to start changing the subject to evidence problems, confirming that uniformly accelerated motion actually does agree with quote naturalia experimenta." Duration: 8:24 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 12 - Galileo's Key Postulate- Relating Vertical Fall to Fall Along Inclines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Explains how Galileo used an incline plane to reach a conclusion about a vertical fall. Opening line: "Now he wants to test it and he's got the problem, the problem I just demonstrated by dropping a coin." Duration: 8:21 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 14 - Inclined Plane Experiments- Modern Reproductions, and the Distinction Between Rolling and Falling.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews inclined plane experiments. Opening line: "Koyr has this book in French studies, Galilean Studies." Duration: 8:53 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 15 - Vertical Fall Experiments- Mersenne, Riccioli, and New Pendular Measurements of Time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews vertical fall experiments. Opening line: "Versand, in particular, seems not to have been that much persuaded by any inclined plane experiment." Duration: 16:27 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 15.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 6 - Part 16 - The Achievement- Four Fundamental Principles of Local Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Concludes the day's lecture with four fundamental principles of local motion. Opening line: "All right, upshot for the night." Duration: 2:25 minutes. Segment: Class 6, Part 16.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 1 - The Galilean Principles: Evidential Problems, and Experimental Challenges in Mechanics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses the limitations of Galileo's evidence supporting his four claims, and the importance of experimental verification. Opening line: "All right, I'm starting with a slide that corresponds to the one I ended with last week, where I listed the four Galilean claims." Duration: 12:33 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 2 - Striking Results in Two New Sciences: Proposition IV, Proposition XXIII, and the Principle of Inertia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Galileo's propositions and how they relate to concept of inertia. Opening line: "All right, striking predictions. Here's another one coming out of proposition six." Duration: 8:58 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 3 - Striking Results in Two New Sciences: Proposition XXX, Proposition XXXVI, and Galileo's Achievement in Day 3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Algebraic analysis of Galileo's propostions 30 and 36. Opening line: "Proposition 30 says something very different. And notice, I didn't even list it as problem, but it's gotta be a problem." Duration: 8:57 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 4 - Projectile Motion: Compounded Horizontal and Vertical Motion, and Some Difficulties of the Theory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Galileo's model of projectile motion, his assumptions, and problems with his arguments. Opening line: "All right. Day four. It starts, this is now the academician." Duration: 15:15 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 5 - Projectile Motion: Galileo's Response to the Difficulties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Galileo's response to problems with his model of projectile motion. Opening line: "And what's Galileo's reply, Salviati's reply? All the difficulties and objections you advance are so well-founded that I deem it impossible to remove them." Duration: 11:51 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 6 - A Proxy for Speed: Height, and the Compounding of Horizontal Motion with Vertical Acceleration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: How Galileo uses height of fall as an indirect measure of speed, and the difficulties involved. Opening line: "The parabola. Now, let me start with a fact that you may or may not know. There's only one parabola just like there's only one circle up to symmetry." Duration: 12:23 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 7 - Galileo's Parabola: Sublimity, and the Striking Result on Maximum Ranges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Galileo's analysis of parabolic motion and cannonball ranges. Opening line: "All right, we've got to this point and now the next slide the reason I broke here is I have to show you what the scaling parameter is for a parabola." Duration: 12:36 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 8 - Galileo's Tables: Symmetry about 45 Degrees, and the Testability of the Theory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Description of Galileo's theoretical ballistic tables in the absence of air resistance, and the interesting fact that they are symmetric around a 45 degree angle. Opening line: "So this is the comment, and now we see what Sagretto says about it." Duration: 10:48 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 9 - Galileo's Tables in Practice: Calibration, and the Problematic Relationship Between Theory and Experiment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: About the difficulties in verifying theoretical results when you cannot duplicate the theoretical conditions--specifically, ballistic trajectories in the absence of air resistance. Opening line: "Now the deep point about this. You're gonna calibrate it how?" Duration: 8:42 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 10 - The Ski-Jump Experiment: the Perfect Empirical Test, Suppressed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes Galileo's Ski-Jump Experiment demonstrating the parabolic shape of a ballistic trajectory. Opening line: "All right, what I wanna do now is turn to Galileo's own test of this theory." Duration: 16:13 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 11 - The State of Galileo's Science of Local Motion: Eight Principles, and Questions Raised.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Explains Galileo's eight principles of motion, and the resulting questions which are considered by subsequent scientists. Opening line: "Galileo is gonna leave the world with eight principles." Duration: 6:44 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 7 - Part 12 - Getting Beyond Mere Conjecture: What Galileo Achieved, and the Problem of Scientific Truth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Galileo's views on the relationship between theory, experimental results, and scientific truth, and the nature of science. Opening line: "Okay. This is from a note that Galileo published concerning the supernova of 1604." Duration: 10:45 minutes. Segment: Class 7, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 1 - Three Post-Copernican Generations- the Key Figures, and the Empirical Limitations of the Theorizing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Introduces several key figures, including, Ren Descartes, Marin Mersenne, and Pierre Gassendi; notes that there are limits to theorizing. Opening line: "So tonight we start what I like to call the third post-Copernican generation when turning to Descartes." Duration: 10:26 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 2 - Ren Descartes- Biography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A brief biography of Ren Descartes Opening line: "All right, this is a chronological table from what surely is the best biography, intellectual biography in English." Duration: 13:21 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 3 - Discourse on Method- Descartes' Theory of Lenses, and the Reduction of Symbolic Methods to Geometry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Overview of Descartes' Discourse on Method; emphasizing optics, refraction, and geometry. Opening line: "Discourse on the method of rightly conducting one's reason, and seeking the truth in the sciences, and in addition, the optics, the meteorology, and the geometry, which are essays in this method." Duration: 16:02 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 4 - The Significance of Descartes' Principia- Its Influence, and the Reconceptualization of Curvilinear Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Overview of Descartes' Principia Philosophiae and Descartes' reconceptualization of curvilinear motion. Opening line: "All right, so the Principia, let's spend the rest of our time on Descartes save for one letter he wrote, that we'll look at next week." Duration: 11:21 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 5 - The Mechanical Philosophy- the "Contact" Constraint on Theorizing, and Vacuums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Overview of mechanical philosophy, the principle of contact and the concept of vacuums Opening line: "And some people, maybe it's in the need to write a new dissertation and say something that hasn't been said before. Are trying to get away from the idea that the principle feature or the mechanical philosophy was contact." Duration: 10:34 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 6 - Descartes' Response to Pyrrhonism- A Unified, Foundationally Secure, Fully Comprehensive Science.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Descartes' response to Pyrrhonism; an introduction to Girard Desargues. Opening line: "Now the big thing here, and I mentioned this before, how is Descartes working with a mechanical philosophy gonna safeguard against error?" Duration: 3:08 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 7 - Two Hard Cases for Mechanical Philosophy- Descartes' Accounts of Magnetism and Gravity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Review of Descartes' accounts for magnetism and gravity. Opening line: "Obviously, a terrible difficulty facing the mechanical philosophy was magnetism." Duration: 7:20 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 9 - The First Two Laws of Natural Motion- the Principle of Inertia, and the Sling Argument.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Defines Descartes' understanding of a law, reviews the principle of inertia and the sling argument. Opening line: "Now we get to the laws, and what in the world does the term law mean?" Duration: 8:55 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 10 - Gassendi and Inertia- the Importance of the Principle in the Context of Celestial Motion, and the Conceptual Change it Represents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Continues with inertia; re-introduces Gassendi. Opening line: "Now, these two laws together, the first and second law, appear to be stating what we now call the principle of inertia." Duration: 8:34 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 11 - The Third Law of Natural Motion- Descartes' Account of Impact.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Descartes' third law of natural motion--the issue of impact. Opening line: "The third law of motion. This is very different." Duration: 8:15 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 12 - Rules of Motion- a Theory of Colliding Spheres, and Its Justification.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews a chart of seven cases created by Eric Aiton and discusses a theory of colliding spheres. Opening line: "So the rules, he proceeds to give in this way you saw them written out." Duration: 7:05 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 13 - Defending the Rules- Spinoza's Defense, and Descartes' Emphasis on Reason Over Experience.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Briefly talks about Spinoza's defense; discusses that experience often seems to contradict the rules. Opening line: "Spinoza tries to do his best with these rules." Duration: 3:46 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 8 - Part 14 - Relativity of Motion- Descartes' View in the Principia, and His View in Le Monde.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Descartes' views on motion. Opening line: "Descartes says in parts of, sections of part two, that I'm reserving more for next week, that geometrically all motion is relative." Duration: 12:43 minutes. Segment: Class 8, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 1 - Descartes on Galileo: the Lack of Foundations for the Theory in Two New Sciences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Descartes' belief that Galileo did not properly establish the foundations for his theory of projectile motion. Opening line: "All right, let me dig in. I'm gonna start with the Descartes letter to Mersenne on Galileo." Duration: 17:32 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 2 - Descartes' Vortex Theory: Three Kinds of Matter, Vortices, and the Creation and Capture of Planets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Outlines Descartes' model of planetary motions as a vortex centered on the Sun, with three kinds of matter for stars, planets, and the space between them. Opening line: "It's worth reading the whole thing. This is the lead in as you see it's way up at article number 30 and part 3. But it's the lead in to the vortex theory." Duration: 13:49 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 3 - Vortices inside of Vortices: Descartes' Theory of Planetary Vortices, and of the Vortices of the Moons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Descartes suggests that vortices within vortices explains how the Galilean satellites go around Jupiter and the Moon goes around the Earth, while the planets go around the Sun. Opening line: "Now, he's right about that. There are vortices inside of vortices." Duration: 11:38 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 4 - A Hypothetico-Explanatory Approach to Theorizing: Descartes' Method of Constructing Theoretically and Empirically Sound Explanations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Descartes keeps his theories firmly linked to the observable, empirical effects, unlike Galileo. Opening line: "There's an approach to theorizing here that's probably worth looking at, and it's my summary of it." Duration: 3:37 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 5 - Celestial Motion in Vortices: Descartes' Copernicanism, and His Definition of Movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Descartes supported a Copernican model over Tychonian, and defined movement as a relative motion rather than absolute. Opening line: "All right, his Copernicanism is fairly easy to explain, that these are his diagrams." Duration: 7:32 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 6 - Quantifying the Tendency to Recede: the Sling Argument, and the Force Displayed by the Tension in the Sling.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses centripetal force and tension in Descartes' vortices, using his diagrams of a spinning sling. Opening line: "Next thing I'm gonna do, there's a passage that starts with article 56 and I'm giving it to you. There are five pages in Latin." Duration: 12:29 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 7 - The Parochiality of Celestial Motion: Descartes' Physics and the Total Variability of Orbital Movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Descartes believed, correctly, that the orbits of the planets are constantly changing, affected by one another, which undercuts the idea that underlying physics can be determined from observation. Opening line: "This is now a totally different thing, but it's fairly important. I changed this slide today because it originally just had the top and the bottom." Duration: 7:36 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 8 - The New Astronomical Physics: Descartes' View, and Six Questions Raised by His Physics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Descartes posed six questions to be answered by astronomy. Opening line: "All right, so we end up with two views of astronomy coming out of this. The Keplerian view we've inherited to develop a mathematical account of the motions that yields calculated longitudes and latitudes that at all times." Duration: 3:59 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 9 - Terrestrial Consequences of Celestial Vortices: Descartes' Theory of the Tides.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes how Descartes applied his vortex theory to explain tides, . Opening line: "At any rate, the questions are important. I wanna do two last things and then take a break." Duration: 7:54 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 10 - The Conclusion of the Principia: Five Principles that Establish the Absolute Certainty of Descartes' Physics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: The conclusion of Descartes' Principia argues that his methods prove his theory. Opening line: "All right what I'm going to end with from the book. And it's gonna be a discussion of Descartes science but picked up initially from what Descartes himself says" Duration: 13:40 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 11 - The Science of Descartes' Principia: a New Way of Turning Data Into Evidence, and Its Shortcomings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Descartes approached science empirically, but did not use it to predict new things which could be tested experimentally. Opening line: "Drake said that Descartes's whole Principia is unscientific and we read it and it seems so far removed from our science that you can legitimately ask, 'Why do we even take this to be science at all.?'. " Duration: 7:41 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 12 - A Modern Example of a Similar Science: Darwin's Theory of Heredity and Evolution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Darwin's approach to the Theory of Evolution was in some ways similar to Descartes' emprical science. Opening line: "Now I forewarned Patrick of this so he can also just say, I don't want to talk about this." Duration: 8:21 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 13 - Descartes' Contributions to Mechanics and Astronomy: Questions Raised, and the Aims of Empirical Research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes the contributions of Descartes to mechanics and astronomy. Opening line: "Contributions to mechanics. There are some really important ones by Descartes." Duration: 11:59 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 9 - Part 14 - The Rise of Modern Science: the Empirical World as the Ultimate Arbiter for Answering Questions About It.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: After 1650, more scientists take as a given that theory must be based on empirical observation. Opening line: "Something very curious happens at this point in time. And it'll show up in this course because almost everything we read from now on in the last five weeks of this course and throughout almost all the second semester, is going to look like modern science to an extent, nothing we've read so far." Duration: 16:00 minutes. Segment: Class 9, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 1 - Review of Several Major Figures: Christiaan Huygens, Isaac Newton, and a Brief Biography of Constantine Huygens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Continues with the theme of mechanics and introduces Christiaan Huygens and Isaac Newton and a brief biography of Constantijn Huygens. Opening line: "Next three classes, which means, not next Tuesday. So this is spread over four weeks, but three classes. They're all gonna look at the period, primarily 1650 to 1680." Duration: 8:22 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 2 - Christiaan Huygens: a Biography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Brief biography of Christiaan Huygens. Opening line: "All right, now Christiaan, the second child. The first thing we really know of him is in the mid 1640s, 1645, 46." Duration: 18:21 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 3 - Huygens' Mechanics: Cycloidal Pendulums, and the Invention of an Extremely Precise Clock.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Chiefly reviews Huygens' invention of an extremely accurate clock. Opening line: "He, because of Alexandre Courrier writing on Descartes and Newton, he portrayed Huygens as a Cartesian." Duration: 8:47 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 4 - Surface Gravity: Two Theory-Mediated Measurements, Via Conical and Cycloidal Pendulums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Huygens' attempts at measuring the strength of surface gravity. Opening line: "As I said, in October of 1659, he got compulsively preoccupied with measuring the strength of surface gravity." Duration: 7:30 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 5 - Extensive Measurements of Surface Gravity: Huygens' Method.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Continues with Huygens' attempts at measuring the strength of surface gravity. Opening line: "These are his instructions. You'll see the date, 1686. 1686 is when Newton is busily finishing the Principia, unbeknownst to Huygens, he's busily finishing this." Duration: 7:49 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 6 - Impact of Hard (Elastic) Spheres: Huygens' Solution, and Several Significant Consequences of It.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Briefly introduces Christopher Wren and John Wallis; discusses impact of spheres and Huygens' solution. Opening line: "Impact. We of course know Descartes' impact." Duration: 6:34 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 7 - Impact of Hard Spheres: Newton's Algebraic Solution, and Huygens' Relativity Principle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews Newton's algebraic solution to the question of impact of hard spheres. Opening line: "Newton has a series of lectures on algebra teaching his students." Duration: 5:53 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 8 - Huygens' Theory of Impact: Against Descartes' Theory, a General Solution, and an Empirically Testable, Striking Result.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Continues discussing Huygen's development of a theory of impact. Opening line: "So whats he do now. Now I am gonna turn to the publication you've seen. The publication I assigned." Duration: 13:34 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 9 - Huygens' Theory of Centrifugal Force: Solving for the Tension in a String.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews Huygen's paper De Vi Centrifuga, which were put as an appendix to Horologium Oscillatorium. Opening line: "All right, next topic is De Vi Centrifuga, this paper which, again, appeared in 1703." Duration: 9:28 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 10 - Tests of Huygen's Theory of Centrifugal Force: Conical Pendulums, Circular Arc Pendulums, and Paraboloids.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes how Huygen tests his theory and the three results. Opening line: "How's he test this theory? Well, there are three results." Duration: 3:40 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 11 - Converging Theory-Mediated Measurements of Surface Gravity: Using Cycloidal and Conical Pendulums to Confirm Different Principles of Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes Huygen using cycloidal and conical pendulums to confirm different principles of motion. Opening line: "All right. I said earlier that Huygens had measured, in 1659, measured surface gravity with a constant height conical pendulum." Duration: 12:04 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 12 - Horologium Oscillatorium: Hypotheses, and Select Propositions from Parts I-III.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Begins an overview of the Horologium Oscillatorium. Opening line: "Different subject. Now I'm gonna just take you through Horologium Oscillatorium for a couple of minutes." Duration: 12:40 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 13 - Horologium Oscillatorium: the Center of Oscillation Problem, and Using Deviations from Idealized Theory to Refine the Theorizing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Continues with an overview of the Horologium Oscillatorium. Opening line: "Now part four of the Horologium Oscillatorium, the last difficult part of the thing." Duration: 12:41 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 14 - Horologium Oscillatorium: the Center of Oscillation for Cycloidal Pendulums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Concludes with an overview of the Horologium Oscillatorium. Opening line: "hese are two of the last three paragraphs of part four." Duration: 4:16 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 10 - Part 15 - Huygens' Accomplishments: Questions Answered, and the Birth of Theoretical Physics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews Huygens' influence on later scientists. Opening line: "I want to accomplish just as now summarizing on the night." Duration: 12:02 minutes. Segment: Class 10, Part 15.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 1 - Astronomy, Mechanics, and Mathematics in the Mid 1600s: a Review of Major Figures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: This begins an overview of important scientists and developments between Descartes and Newton. Opening line: "So look, what we're doing, what we're in the middle of is three classes interrupted by a holiday on November 11th, three classes looking at the period from the early 1640s." Duration: 10:44 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 2 - Alternatives to the Area Rule: Ismal Bullialdus, Vincent Wing, and Three New Methods for Calculating Orbits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Ismael Boulliau and Vincent Wing developed alternatives to Keplers Laws. Opening line: "All right. The first person to come along and offer a full system alternative to Kepler's was Ismael Boulleau." Duration: 9:45 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 3 - New Technology: Huygens' Clocks, Telescopes, and the Discovery of Titan and Saturn's Ring.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Christian and Constantine Huygens developed very accurate astronomical clocks and telescopes. Christian discovered Titan, the largest satellite of Saturn, and identified a previously mysterious feature as a ring around Saturn. Opening line: "There were major advances in observational astronomy during this time." Duration: 8:32 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 4 - Observational Astronomy in Bologna: Cassini's Observations at San Petronio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Cassini executed high-precision observations of the sun and planets, producing very accurate measurements of their motions and features. Opening line: "The next few slides are going to be focused on Bologna and I will confess to everybody there is nothing I am more vain about. Than my own photographs." Duration: 11:29 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 5 - Thomas Streete: Astronomia Carolina, Tables, and Another New Method for Calculating Orbits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Thomas Street published Astronomia Carolina, in which he promoted proposals and observations originally made by Horrocks. Opening line: "1661 is the publication of Thomas Street's Astronomia Carolina." Duration: 10:14 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 6 - Nicholas Mercator: Another New Method for Calculating Orbits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Mercator published his own alternative to the area rule for orbits. Opening line: "Just continuing for a moment now, this is jumping ahead to 1676." Duration: 10:13 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 7 - The Founding of the Royal Society: the Fellows, and Philosophical Transactions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: The Royal Society of London was founded in 1663, and included many of the great scientists of the time. The Philosophical Transactions became an important mechanism for scientific communication. Opening line: "I spoke before magnetical philosophy. What I'm gonna shift on to for the next few minutes is England right after Street, before and after Street." Duration: 16:27 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 8 - Hooke's Micrographia: Microscopic Observations of Small Entities, and a Brief Biography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Robert Hooke made important discoveries with a microscope. Opening line: "So picture yourself in France now. They've got this society forming, and they have their own journal, etcetra." Duration: 4:59 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 9 - The Founding of the Royal Academy: the Scholars, the Royal Observatory, and Cassini's Observations of Saturn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: The Royal Academy of Sciences was founded in 1666, with Cassini the first royal astronomer of France. Opening line: "All right, so England is in the process of forming the royal society, with Marx' success." Duration: 7:43 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 10 - Cassini's Effort to Rebuild Observational Astronomy: Picard's Expedition to Hven, and Richer's Expedition to Cayenne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Cassini set out to analyze Kepler's mechanics starting with new accurate observations, which takes 80 years. Opening line: "Once Cassini was there, remember, he had already decided in Bologna that Astronomy had to be built from the ground up." Duration: 14:09 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 11 - Correcting Chromatic Aberration: Newton and the Refraction Indices of Different Colors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: In 1672, Newton published an explanation of chromatic aberration, and a new telescope design (the first reflecting telescope) which does not have chromatic aberration. Opening line: "It's in 1672, while Roche is down in Cayenne, that Newton publishes his first paper." Duration: 4:38 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 12 - The Eclipses of Io: Cassini and the Speed of Light.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Observations of eclipses of Io caused the first speculation that planetary observations must be corrected for a measurable speed of light. Cassini resisted this idea for a long time. Opening line: "The tables were saying the eclipse should happen at a certain time, and the kind of error was eight minutes in time." Duration: 5:42 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 13 - Observational Astronomy in England: the Greenwich Observatory, Flamsteed's Research, and the Professionalization of the Scientific Community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: John Flamsteed, the first royal astronomer of England, founded the Greenwich Observatory. Flamsteed used the observatory to create a new star catalog, replacing Tycho's. Opening line: "Now England doesn't have a Royal Observatory and France not only has one, they're sending expeditions out." Duration: 9:34 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 14 - Pressing Issues in Astronomy in 1679: Seven Ways of Calculating Planetary Orbits, and Ten Open Questions.
