scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes the status of astronomy in 1679, and the top ten unanswered questions of the time. Opening line: "All right, cuz what I wanna look at now is where astronomy stood, I'll finish tonight with this, where astronomy stood in 1679." Duration: 12:24 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 11 - Part 15 - Hooke on Attractive Powers in Celestial Bodies: a Guess at Universal Gravity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: In 1674, Hooke proposed a universal gravity which causes all celestial bodies to be attracted to each other. Hooke later accused Newton of stealing the idea from him. Opening line: "Meanwhile, we have Hooke sitting there in the royal society." Duration: 6:35 minutes. Segment: Class 11, Part 15.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 1 - Isaac Newton: a Biography, 1642-1676.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A brief biography of Isaac Newton from 1642 to 1676. Opening line: "This is the last class until very near the end of the next semester where I have this broad focus instead of looking almost proposition by proposition." Duration: 17:07 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 2 - Isaac Newton: a Biography, 1676-1727.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A brief biography of Isaac Newton from 1676 to 1727. Opening line: "So just continuing, he has an exchange with Lagnus over the calculus in the mid 1670s." Duration: 19:24 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 3 - The Early Mathematics: Newton's Work While at Trinity College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton's early work in mathematics while at Trinity College, Cambridge; includes his work in developing calculus; a mention of his personality. Opening line: "We have his college notebook when he was first doing math and work in optics." Duration: 8:00 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 4 - Newton's Development of the Calculus: Infinite Equations, A Treatise of the Method of Fluxions, and Curvature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton's further work in calculus; derivatives; infinte equations; method of fluxions; curves. Opening line: "This is the first tract on Calculus. It's called Resolving Problems By Motion." Duration: 15:00 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 5 - The Optics: an Experimentum Crucis, the Relationship between Hypotheses and Experimental Results, and Newton's Wish for a Natural Science Supported by the Greatest Evidence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton's work in optics, including how to find imperfections; his first paper on light and colors; the experiment of the cross. Opening line: "This is from the same little notebook. This page is describing how to grind lenses." Duration: 16:10 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 6 - A Proposed Interpretation of How Newton Thought: Solving Problems, and then Asking Questions that Went Beyond Them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Newton's capacity to concentrate on a problem for a substantial length and very effectively. Opening line: "Let me say a couple things about now Newton and my picture of him, then we will look the rest of the class at the specific readings for today." Duration: 5:54 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 7 - Newton's Mechanics: Laws of Motion for a Theory of Impact, and Some Consequences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Introduces Newtonian mechanics and his interrest in angular momentum. Opening line: "Now, the one warning on this, the form in which I've put on assigned reading, the nine page document, is from Paravell's book, which you've already been reading for this week." Duration: 11:28 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 8 - Newton's Mechanics: a General Theory of Impact, and some Experimental Difficulties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Continues with Newtonian mechanics and his interrest in impact; mentions Newton's Third Law of Motion. Opening line: " Duration: 6:20 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 9 - Newton on Circular Motion: the Solution for Uniform Circular Motion, and the Inverse-Square Tendency of the Planets to Recede from the Sun.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses Newton's work on circular motion and its implications. Opening line: "Next document, this is a two page document. I think I included the actual manuscript. It's in Latin." Duration: 10:13 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 10 - The Moon Test: Concluding that the Moon Isn't Influenced by Terrestrial Gravity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Introduces the Moon Test and discusses Newton's calculations for the force of gravity. Opening line: "Now Newton does something rather striking with it. The term has come to be known, and you'll hear it all the rest of this course and next semester, the Moon Test." Duration: 4:16 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 11 - Two Proposed Accounts of the Purpose of the Moon Test: to Establish Universal Gravity, and to Establish Copernicanism over Tychonism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Continues discussing the Moon Test and Newton's calculations for the force of gravity. Opening line: "Now, what's he doing here? He's already figured out, three halves power rule, inverse square, given his solution for the circle." Duration: 12:30 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 12 - Motion Along a Cycloid: Newton on the Isochronism, and the Law, of Cycloidal Pendulums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Reviews Newton's work on motion long a cycloid; mentions Christopher Wren's work on the rectification problem for the cycloid; continues with Newton's work on vibrations. Opening line: "This is a letter from Newton to Oldenburg after he received the complimentary copy of Horologium Oscillatorium. " Duration: 8:00 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 12 - Part 13 - De Gravitatione et Aequipondio Fluidorum: a Reductio of Descartes' Theory of Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Review's Newton's De Gravitatione et Aequipondio Fluidorum; discuses Newton's definition of place, and then uses it to disprove Descartes. Opening line: "There's a manuscript we don't know how to date. It's called On gravity and the of Fluids." Duration: 6:32 minutes. Segment: Class 12, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 1 - Newton-Hooke Correspondence: a Proposed Method for Detecting the Earth's Rotation, and Ideas for Analyzing Curvilinear Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Letters between Hooke and Newton discuss directly measuring the rotation of the Earth, and measuring curved motion. Opening line: "And then Descartes' Principia which he, in spite of the influence it had on him, he really did not like the book very much at all." Duration: 22:51 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 2 - Newton-Hooke Correspondence: Hooke's Proposal of Using Forces Towards a Single Point.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Letters between Hooke and Newton discuss an attractive force pulling toward a single point, resulting in curvilinear motion. Opening line: "What I do want to show you, though, is what we, I think almost all of us who've worried about this, feel that Hooke contributed with this." Duration: 7:03 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 3 - Newton-Flamsteed Correspondence: Flamsteed's Proposed Account of Cometary Motion, and Newton's Response.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Letters between Flamsteed and Newton suggest that two comets were actually just one comet headed toward the sun and then away from the sun. Opening line: "Well, there's a comet that shows up going from north to south." Duration: 13:11 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 4 - Further Newton-Flamsteed Correspondence Concerning the 1680/1681 Comet: Flamsteed's Calculations of the Comet's Trajectory, and Newton's Response.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Flamsteed sent calculations of the two comets' trajectories to Newton, trying to prove they were the same orbit. Opening line: "So Flamsteed gets this letter, defends himself at length." Duration: 3:58 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 5 - Transitioning Towards Universal Gravity: Newton's Evolving Thought on Cometary Motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton initially dismissed the idea that comets could both approach and recede from the Sun, but later changed his mind. Opening line: "We have one further document. This is from Rupners paper of year 2000." Duration: 6:31 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 6 - Priority Dispute Over Inverse Square: the Conflict Between Newton and Hooke, and the Incipience of De Motu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A dispute started over whether Hooke or Newton had first invented the inverse square law of force in orbital mechanics. Newton nearly stopped working on the project, but finally sent Halley a subsequently lost document believed to be titled De Motu. Opening line: "This story has become legendary. Many people have embellished it. What's fascinating about it is we have exactly one source of evidence about what happened." Duration: 7:45 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 7 - Generalizing Uniform Circular Motion: Hooke's Proposal Concerning Centripetal Forces, and Theorem 1 of De Motu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton extended his inverse square theory from uniform circular motion to non-circular motion. Opening line: "So Newton knows how to do uniform circular motion. And I'm going to do it the way Hooke did it. I mean, Hooke. The way Huygens did it." Duration: 10:59 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 8 - De Motu Corporum in Gyrum: Definitions, Hypotheses, and a Comparison with Horologium Oscillatorium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes the definitions and basic hypotheses of De Motu. Opening line: "All right, let me jump into Day Mo two. I'm not gonna go through it text by text. You can read it on your own." Duration: 11:37 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 9 - De Motu Corporum in Gyrum: Problem 1 and Problem 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Further mathematical analysis of De Motu. Opening line: "Newton now does three problems, the first problem looks really weird and I trust most of you, if you read with any care, thought why in the world is he doing this?" Duration: 12:12 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 10 - De Motu Corporum in Gyrum: Problem 3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Further mathematical analysis of De Motu. Opening line: "This is for the Keplerian ellipse. So it's the same ellipse now, but we are sweeping out equal areas and equal times about a focus not about a center." Duration: 6:39 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 11 - The Original, Handwritten De Motu: Replacing 'Gravitatis' with 'Vis Centripetae'.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton switched from using the term 'gravitas' to the term 'vis centripeta', or centripetal force. Opening line: "This the actual document in facsimile. You can see the scratched out first hypothesis and replace." Duration: 4:56 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 12 - A Controversial Scholium in De Motu: Deriving the Ellipse from the Inverse Square.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton derived elliptical motion from his inverse square centripetal force. Opening line: "Problem three. A body orbits an ellipse. There is required to find the law of centrifugal force tending to a focus of the ellipse." Duration: 4:44 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 13 - De Motu Corporum in Gyrum: Theorem 4, Problem 4, and Two Key Scholia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Further mathematical analysis of De Motu. Opening line: "Theorem for supposing that centripetal force be reciprocally proportional to the square root of the distance from the center." Duration: 12:30 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 13.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 14 - De Motu Corporum in Gyrum: Problem 5, and Trajectories Under Inverse-Square and Uniform Gravity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton derived ballistic trajectories under uniform gravity with no air resistance. Opening line: "We've done everything we need to for this case of inverse square except direct vertical fall." Duration: 5:08 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 14.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 15 - De Motu Corporum in Gyrum: Problems 6 and 7, and Motion Under Resistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton then derived trajectories in the presence of air resistance. Opening line: "What he goes on to do in the last problems and I don't want to keep you too long, so I'm going to be very sketchy here." Duration: 6:59 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 15.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 13 - Part 16 - The Principal Accomplishments of De Motu: Keplerian Motion, Galilean Motion, and the Connection Between Mathematical Results and the Actual World.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes the principles from Newtons De Motu. Opening line: "So we've got a series of results. I'm gonna state them fairly carefully now." Duration: 2:51 minutes. Segment: Class 13, Part 16.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 1 - A Summary of De Motu Corporum in Gyrum: Principal Results, and the Loose Ends that Led to the Principia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes the main principles from De Motu, and points out three places where De Motu does not adequately justify conclusions. Opening line: "You've seen this slide before, when we reviewed astronomy between 16 between Descartes and Newton." Duration: 9:31 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 1.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 2 - De Motu Sphaericorum Corporum in Fluidis: a New Version of De Motu Corporum in Gyrum, and Five Laws.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Describes a second version of De Motu, emphasizing the changes between the two. Opening line: "All right, this is a document you can see at the top, the title. So this document is written in the hand of Humphrey Newton, his amanuensis at the time, with Isaac going in and making the changes, and the principle change on this page, the change that stands out, is he's got hypothesis one, hypothesis two, hypothesis three, hypothesis four all crossed out to the word law lex." Duration: 11:03 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 2.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 3 - Lemma 2: a Proof (from the New Laws in Fluidis), in the General Case, that Distance is Proportional to Time Squared.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: A mathematical proof that distance covered under uniform acceleration is proportional to the square of the time. Opening line: "So, this proof is worth looking at. One of you, Issac challenged it last time, how it's even legitimate." Duration: 5:30 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 3.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 4 - The Copernican Scholium: Inordinate Complexity in the Actual Planetary Motions, and the Difficulty of Determining Correct Keplerian Orbits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: The center of gravity is affected by all the planets, so orbits are far more complex than simple ellipses, and are never repeated. Opening line: "Next is a long paragraph added to the scholium after theorem four. Theorem four is the three halves power rule for ellipses." Duration: 16:13 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 4.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 5 - The Copernican Scholium: a Proof of the Inordinate Complexity, Without the Notion of Universal Gravity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Outlines a proof of the complexity of orbits, by looking at combining centers of gravity. Opening line: "What's the proof? Okay, what's the principle of center of gravity? Well, it's a balance." Duration: 7:25 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 5.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 6 - A Second New Scholium in Fluidis: Problems 4 and 5, and the Moon Test Revisited.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton discusses motion through a fluid, concluding that the ether that the planets move through has no resistance. He also concludes that the Moon's orbit proves the Earth's centripetal force decreases as the inverse square of distance. Opening line: "All right, the other thing that's added, there's a diagram changed in problem five. It's interesting, the diagram changed but the words did not. So I don't know what he had in mind when he changed the diagram." Duration: 11:37 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 6.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 7 - Newton-Flamsteed Correspondence: Flamsteed on the Puzzlingly Regular Motions of the Jovian Moons, and Newton on the Possible Interaction Between Jupiter and Saturn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Letters between Flamsteed and Newton show that the orbits of Jupiters moons follow the three halves power law of Kepler, if you account for the speed of light as measured by Romer. They also speculate on gravitational interaction between Jupiter and Saturn. Opening line: "All right, what happens is, Newton starts a correspondence sometime in December of 1684 with Flamsteed." Duration: 11:29 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 7.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 8 - Newton-Flamsteed Correspondence: Flamsteed on the Lack of Observed Interaction Between Jupiter and Saturn, and Newton's Concern with Jupiter's Discrepancy from the 3/2 Power Rule.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: In letters, Flamsteed doubts interaction between Jupiter and Saturn, and Newton talks about the small affect that Jupiter has on the motion of the Sun. Opening line: "All right, here's Flamsteed's answer, which will indeed answer Corey's question." Duration: 11:35 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 8.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 9 - Further Revisions to De Motu: Select Definitions in De Motu Corporum in Mediis Regulariter Cedentibus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes the changes in yet another version of De Motu. Opening line: "This is a document, if it's a fragment. He's changed the title again on the motion of bodies in regularly yielding media." Duration: 13:33 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 9.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 10 - Further Revisions to De Motu: Select Laws in Cedentibus, and the Notion of Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton introduces the concept of mass independent of discussion of gravity. Opening line: "Now the, oh, the laws. What is new here is, and this is again Heravel's translation, because law four has the relative motion of bodies enclosed as a given space." Duration: 9:19 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 10.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 11 - How Newton Discovered the Law of Gravity: the Accepted View, and a Variant of It as Presented in De Motu Corporum, Liber Secundus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Discusses how Newton may have discovered the Law of Gravity. Opening line: "But now we've got something very significant because now we can actually see the principle that's called the Law of Gravity almost staring us in the face." Duration: 29:46 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 11.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 12 - Universal Gravity: a Sequence of Increasingly Implausible Claims.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Newton proposes universal gravity, acting between all bodies proportional to their masses and inversely to the square of their distance. Opening line: "What's happened here is we've seen a sequence of proposals. There are 11 stages of this that form the theory of universal gravity that Newton's gonna defend in the Principia." Duration: 3:44 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 12.

did.unittitle: Philosophy 167: Class 14 - Part 13 - A Summary of the Progression to Newton's Principia: Milestones, Questions Raised, and Three Revolutions in Evidence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synopsis: Summarizes the scientific advances which led up to Newton's Law of Gravity, and the remaining questions to be resolved in Principia. Opening line: "So to end the course, five minutes, it's a series of three comments." Duration: 6:08 minutes. Segment: Class 14, Part 13.
